Circumstances of a Poor Man's Offering of a Ball of Flour and Immediately Receiving Retribution (40) Circumstances of a Poor Man's Offering of a Ball of Flour
and Immediately Receiving Retribution In the past, there was a person who lived in poverty. He worked for others and obtained
six sheng of flour. He brought it home to support his wife and children.
On the way, he saw a monk carrying a bowl and a staff, going around begging for food. He immediately thought in his mind:
That monk has a dignified appearance and proper demeanor, he is very respectable. If I could give him a meal, wouldn't that be wonderful?
At that time, the monk knew what he was thinking, so he followed the poor man to a riverbank. The poor man then said to the monk:
I have some flour now and I want to give it to you. Can you eat it?
The monk replied:
I can only eat that.
He then spread out his robe on the riverbank, asking the monk to sit down. He mixed a pint of flour into a ball and gave it to him, thinking:
If this monk is a person who strictly observes the precepts and has attained the Way, may I become a small king in the present.
The monk received the flour and said to the poor man:
Why is it so little?
Why is it too little?
This person thought that this monk ate a lot, so he mixed another liter of flour, made it into a ball, and gave it to him, making a wish:
If this monk is a person who strictly observes precepts and has attained the Way, may I become the king of two small countries.
The monk said again:ğŸ”½Why is it too little?
Why is it too small?
The poor man thought to himself:
Only this monk seems to eat a lot. I gave him that much flour, but he still complained that it was too little. However, since I have already invited him, I must provide for him.
He then mixed two liters of flour, made it into a ball, and gave it to him, and made another wish:
If this monk is a person who strictly observes precepts and has attained the Way, may I presently obtain the leadership of four small countries.
The monk said again:ğŸ”½Why is it too little?
Why is it too small?
The remaining two pints were all mixed to make balls and given to the monk. He also made a vow, saying:
If this monk is a pure and precept-observing person, may I become the king of Varanasi, rule the four small countries, and attain the path of seeing the truth.
The monk obtained the flour and still complained that it was too little.
The poor man said:
Please eat first. If it is not enough, I will take off my clothes to trade for food and drink to provide for you together.
The monk ate and only finished one pint, and the rest was returned to the owner.
The poor man asked:
Venerable one, you previously complained that the flour was too little, but now why did you not finish it?
The monk replied:
When you first gave me a ball of flour, I was just seeking to become a king of a small country, so I said:
'Your wish is too small.'
The second lump of dough, you wished to become two small kings of countries, so I said:
'Your wish is too small.'
The third lump of dough, you wished to become four small kings of countries, so I said:
'Your mind's wish is too small.'
The fourth lump of dough, you wished to become the king of the country of Varanasi, leading four small countries, and to later attain the fruits of seeing the truth, so I said:
'Your wish is too small.'
Do not be dissatisfied with the small amount.
At that time, the poor man gave rise to doubts in his mind:
If I were to attain the kingship of five countries in the present, this matter is not small, I fear it is not real.
He further contemplated:
Being able to know my mind, he must be a sage, a great field of merit, he should not deceive me.
The practitioner, knowing this, immediately threw his alms bowl into the sky and flew away, transforming his body to fill the sky;
he also transformed into a small body, like a tiny particle.

With one body he made countless bodies, and with countless bodies he combined them into one body. Water flowed from the upper part of his body and fire from the lower part. He walked on water as if on land, and on land as if on water. He performed the eighteen transformations and said to the poor man:
Make great vows well, do not have any doubts.
He then disappeared.
At that time, this poor man was heading towards the city of Varanasi, and on the way he saw a minister.
The minister, having seen him, stared at his appearance and said to him:
Aren't you so-and-so's son?
He replied:
I am.
He asked:
Why are you in such rags?
He replied:
I lost my parents at an early age, and my family was wiped out. No one looked after me, so I became impoverished and ragged like this.
The prime minister then informed the king of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«:
The son of someone close to the king is now outside the gate, extremely poor and haggard.
The king then issued an order:
Have him brought forward.
He questioned him in detail and recognized him as a relative. The king then said to him:
Stay close to me and never leave.
Seven days later, the king fell ill and passed away. The ministers discussed among themselves:
Since there is no heir to the throne, this poor son, who is a relative of the king, should be jointly appointed as the king of VÄrÄá¹‡asÄ«.
He then ruled the four countries, but later became tyrannical.
The ascetic monk was sitting in the sky in front of the king's palace, with his legs crossed, and said to him:
In the past, you made a vow to attain insight into the truth.
Why do you now commit many evils, contradicting your original self?
He also spoke various teachings to the king.

After hearing the teachings, the king regretted his previous evil deeds, reformed his mistakes, felt ashamed and remorseful, and single-mindedly practiced the path, attaining the stage of stream-entry.

The poor woman's immediate karmic reward from offering two coins (41) The poor woman's immediate karmic reward from offering two coins: In the past, in the Dayan Mountain, many sages and saints lived in seclusion among the monks.
People from various regions and countries, hearing the name of the mountain, made offerings in large numbers.
There was an elder who, together with his relatives, went to make offerings.
There was a poor woman who begged for a living, and she thought:
Now, the elders are bringing offerings to the mountain, they must be holding a gathering, I should go and beg.
She then headed for the mountain.
When she arrived at the mountain, she saw the elder who had set up various delicacies to make offerings to the monks. She thought to herself:
That person cultivated merit in his past life, and today he is wealthy and noble. Now he is making more merit, which will be even greater.
I did not make merit in my past life, and in this life I am poor and suffering. If I do not make merit now, it will be even worse in the future.
After thinking this, he cried and was unhappy. He also thought to himself:
I once picked up two coins in the filth. I have always treasured them, waiting for a time when begging was not successful, and then I could use them to buy food and drink to sustain myself.
Now I will take them to give as alms to the assembly of monks. I can go without food for a day or two, but I will not die.
After the monks had finished eating, he took the two coins and gave them as alms.
The mountain monks' rule was that when someone made a donation, the rector would stand before the assembly and chant a prayer.
At that time, the senior monk did not allow the rector to chant the prayer, but chanted it himself.
The junior monks and others deeply resented this and thought:
You got two small coins from that begging woman, but the senior monk disdained her and did not give her a blessing as usual. Why is that?
The senior monk then left half of his food to give to the woman.
Seeing that the senior monk gave her a lot, everyone else also gave her a lot.
The woman then got a heavy load of food and drink, and was extremely happy:
I just made a donation and now I've gotten a reward.
She then carried the food and drink out of the mountain and went to rest under a tree.
It happened that the king's chief consort had passed away seven days earlier, and the king sent messengers to inspect the country, looking for someone with blessings and virtues
who could be the consort.
The physiognomists said that under that yellow cloud cover, there must be a virtuous person.
They then took her to the tree.
They saw that the woman had a lustrous complexion and the marks of blessings and virtues. The tree bent its branches to shade her, and the light and shadows did not move. The physiognomists said:
This woman is blessed and virtuous, she is worthy to be the queen.

She was bathed with fragrant water, given the queen's clothes, not too big or small, just right for her body. With a thousand carriages and ten thousand horses, surrounded by attendants, she was brought to the palace.
The king was delighted upon seeing her, and his heart was filled with respect. After some time, he privately thought to himself:
The reason I have obtained this wealth and blessings is because of giving money.
Now those monks have become a great benefactor to me.
He then said to the king:
Before, I was lowly, but the king saw fit to promote me and make me a human again. Please allow me to repay the kindness of those monks.
The king said:
Do as you wish.
The queen then loaded food and drink, as well as precious treasures, into a carriage and went to the mountain to offer food to the monks. After the meal, she made offerings of treasures.
The senior monk did not rise, but sent the rector to chant the blessings, not doing it himself.
The king and queen said:ğŸ”½Why is it that the senior monk does not chant the blessings himself?
In the past, when I gave two coins, you gave me a blessing;
Now, when I bring precious treasures in a cart, you don't give me a blessing?

The young monks all resented the senior monk, thinking, In the past, when a poor woman gave two coins, he gave her a blessing, but now, when the king's wife brings precious treasures in a cart, he doesn't give her a blessing. Is he senile?
At that time, the senior monk then expounded the true Dharma to the king's wife, saying:
Your Ladyship!
You think resentfully of me:
'In the past, when I gave two coins, you gave me a blessing, but now, when I bring precious treasures in a cart, you don't give me a blessing.'
In our Buddha Dharma, we do not value precious treasures, but only value the good mind.
Your Ladyship!

When you gave two coins in the past, your good mind was extremely superior, but when you gave precious treasures later, you were arrogant and self-important, and therefore I do not give you a blessing now.
Young monks!
Do not blame me, you should deeply understand the mind of leaving home.
The young monks each felt ashamed and attained the path of stream-entry.
The king's wife listened to the Dharma, felt ashamed and delighted, and also attained the path of stream-entry.
After listening to the Dharma, she bowed and left.

The Causes and Conditions of KÄtyÄyana and His Wife Selling Themselves to Hold a Feast and Immediately Receiving Retribution (43) The Causes and Conditions of KÄtyÄyana and His Wife Selling Themselves to Hold a Feast and Immediately Receiving Retribution In the past, there was a person named KÄtyÄyana. He and his wife were extremely poor and made a living by hiring themselves out.

Because I did not do good deeds in my previous life, I am poor today.
Just as that elder, having previously accumulated merit, now also accumulates merit;
I now have no merit, and in the future, my suffering will only increase.
Having thought this, he wept sorrowfully, and tears fell onto his wife's arm.
His wife asked her husband:
Why are you shedding tears?
He replied:
Seeing others cultivating merit always leads to happiness. I despise my own poverty and lowliness, and have nothing to cultivate merit with, which is why I am shedding tears.
His wife said:
What benefit is there in shedding tears?
You can sell me to others to obtain wealth and cultivate merit.
Her husband said:
If we are to sell each other, how can I survive on my own?
His wife said:
If you fear not being able to survive and do not agree to this, then I will sell myself together with you to cultivate merit.
Then the couple took each other to a wealthy family and said:
Now, my husband and I, with this lowly body, request to trade for gold coins.
The host asked:
How many coins do you want?
He replied:
I want ten gold coins.
The host said:
If you get the money now but cannot repay me after seven days, you and your wife will become my slaves.
The agreement was made, and he took the money to the temple. He held a gathering there.
The couple ground rice together and encouraged each other, saying:
Today we can use our own strength to create blessings. Later, if we belong to another family, how can we do as we please?

Thus, day and night, they diligently prepared for the gathering. On the sixth day, they were about to hold the gathering, but the ruler of that country also wanted to hold a gathering and came to compete for the date. The monks all said:
Those who have accepted it cannot change it.
The king heard this and said:
What kind of petty person dares to compete with me for the date of the assembly?
He then sent someone to tell Kirti:
You should avoid my date.
Kirti replied:
I will not avoid it.
This went on three times, with the same words as before.
The king wondered why and went to the monastery himself, telling the man:
Why don't you do it on another day? Why do you compete with me for the date?
He replied:
Only one day is my own. After that, it belongs to another family and I cannot do it again.
The king then asked:
Why can't you do it?
The one who sold himself said:
I think back to my past life when I did not do meritorious deeds. Today I am poor and suffering. If I do not do it now, I fear it will be even worse later.
I feel this way, so I am selling myself to trade for gold coins to do meritorious deeds, wanting to end this suffering.
After seven days, if they have no wealth to repay the other, they will become slaves.
Now it is the sixth day, and tomorrow will be full, so they are arguing over the day of death.
When the king heard this, he felt deep pity and sighed in admiration:

You truly understand the suffering of poverty and are able to exchange your impermanent body for a permanent body, your impermanent wealth for permanent wealth, and your impermanent life for a permanent life.
He then allowed the assembly to be held. The king took off his own and the queen's clothes and jewelry and gave them to KÄ«ra and his wife, and granted them a fief of ten villages for their merit.
Those who can sincerely cultivate merit and virtue will attain the reward of flowers in the present, and it is still like this, let alone the fruits and rewards they will receive in the future.
Judging from this, all worldly people who wish to escape suffering should diligently cultivate merit and virtue. How can they indulge in laziness and negligence?

The Conditions of a Novice Monk Saving Ants and Receiving the Retribution of a Long Life in a Flood (44) The Conditions of a Novice Monk Saving Ants and Receiving the Retribution of a Long Life in a Flood: In the past, there was an arhat monk who raised a novice monk. He knew that this novice monk would definitely die after seven days. He gave him leave to return home and on the seventh day, he ordered him to come back.

The novice monk took leave of his teacher and immediately returned home. On the way, he saw many ants being carried away by the water, their lives about to end. He gave rise to a compassionate mind, took off his kasaya robe, used it to dam the water, and saved the ants, placing them in a high and dry place, and they all survived.
On the seventh day, he returned to his teacher.

The teacher was very surprised and immediately entered concentration, using his heavenly eye to observe. He knew that he had no other blessings and only received this way because of the conditions of saving the ants, not dying for seven days and extending his life.

(47) The Causes and Conditions of the Elder's Son Seeing the Buddha and Seeking a Long Life. In the past when the Buddha was in the world, there was an elder's son, five or six years old.
An astrologer predicted that he had complete blessings and virtues, but only a short lifespan.
He brought him to the six non-Buddhist teachers, hoping to seek a long life, but the six teachers were all unable to provide the method for a long life.
He brought him to the Buddha and said to the Buddha:
This child has a short lifespan. I only wish that the World-Honored One would grant him a long life.
The Buddha said:
There is no such method that can grant a long life.
He earnestly said to the Buddha:
Please show me a skillful means.
The Buddha then instructed him, saying:
When you reach the city gate, if you see someone coming out, bow to them, and if you see someone coming in, also bow to them.
At that time, a ghost spirit transformed into the body of a brahmin, wanting to come into the city. The child bowed to him, and the ghost made a wish, saying:
May you live a long life.
This ghost was the ghost that killed children, but the way of ghosts is that they cannot speak twice. By promising a long life, they cannot kill again.
Because of his humility, patience, and respect, he was able to prolong his life.

The Story of the Elder's Son Working as a Guest and Holding a Feast to Attain Immediate Retribution (48) The Story of the Elder's Son Working as a Guest and Holding a Feast to Attain Immediate Retribution: In the past when the Buddha was in the world, there was an elder's son who lost his parents early. He was alone and destitute, working as a guest to make a living.

He heard someone say that the Heaven of the Thirty-three was extremely joyful, and he also heard others say that by making offerings to the Buddha and Sangha, one could definitely be reborn there. He then asked others, saying:
How much money is needed to make offerings to the Buddha and the Sangha?
At that time, people said:
Thirty taels of gold will be enough to hold the assembly.
He then went to the market to look for work.
By the side of the market, there was a very wealthy elder who hired him for work. The elder asked:
What kind of work can you do now?
He replied:
I can do all kinds of work.
For three years of work, how much will you ask for?
He replied:
I will ask for thirty taels of gold.
The elder, hearing that he was skilled in all kinds of work, immediately hired him.
As he was upright, he made double the usual profit in various shops selling gold, silver, copper, and iron.
After the days were up, he asked the elder for his wages in gold.
The elder asked:
What will you do with the gold you receive now?
He replied:
I want to make offerings to the Buddha and Sangha.
The elder said:
I will now assist you and provide various vessels and grains for you to make food. You just invite the Buddha and the Sangha.
He then went to the monks' quarters to invite the Buddha and the Sangha.
The Buddha had the Sangha all accept his invitation, while the Buddha stayed in his own room. The Sangha all accepted the invitation of the elder's son.
It happened to be a festival day, and many people sent various foods to give to the Sangha.
The Sangha ate their fill and went to the elder's house.
At that time, the elder's son personally served the food. The senior monk said:
Put a little.
In succession, they all said to put a little, until the end of the line.
At that time, the elder's son cried and was distressed. After three years of hardship, I prepared this food and drink, hoping the Sangha would eat it;
The Sangha did not eat it. I sought to be reborn in the heavens, but I will definitely not be reborn.
He went to where the Buddha was and said to the Buddha:
The monks did not eat my offerings, and my wish will certainly not be fulfilled.
The Buddha said:
Did you eat little?
He replied:
They all ate little.
The Buddha said:
If you had not eaten, your wish would have been fulfilled, let alone eating little and not being fulfilled?
The young man was delighted and returned to eat.
At that time, the monks finished their meal and returned.
At that time, there were five hundred merchants who had returned from the sea and entered the city to seek food and drink.
At that time, the world was in famine and no one would give to them.
Someone said to them:
The son of the elder is holding a feast today, he will certainly have food and drink.

At that time, the son of the elder heard that there were merchants, and was delighted to give them food. The five hundred merchants were all satisfied, and all their followers were also fully satiated.
The lowest merchant took off a pearl worth ten thousand taels of gold and gave it to him;
The best head was given a pearl worth a hundred thousand taels of gold.
The five hundred merchants each gave a pearl and a copper helmet to the elder's son, but he did not dare accept them.
He went to ask the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
This is the flower retribution. Just accept it without suffering. Later you will definitely be reborn in the heavens. There is no need to fear.
The host elder had no other sons, only a daughter, whom he gave to the young man.
In this way, the family business became extremely prosperous, the best in the city of Shravasti.
When the elder passed away, King Prasenajit heard of his wisdom and insight, and begged to give him all his family's wealth.
The flower retribution is like this, its fruit will come later.

49. The Conditions of Offering Food in a Buddha's Bowl and Attaining Immediate Retribution (49) The Conditions of Offering Food in a Buddha's Bowl and Attaining Immediate Retribution. In the past when the Buddha was in the world, there were five Brahman brothers, the first named Yexia,
the second named Wu Gou, the third named Jia Fan Bo Ti, the fourth named Su Tuo Yi;
the four older brothers entered the mountains to study the Way and attained the five supernatural powers.
The youngest brother, named Funna, saw the Buddha begging for food and offered him a full bowl of fine white rice.
At that time, Funna always made a living by plowing and planting. When he had finished plowing and planting, he returned home.
One day, he went out to the fields and saw that the seedlings in the fields had turned into golden crops, all several feet tall. After harvesting, they grew back as before.
The king heard about it and also came to harvest, but he could not finish. In this way, everyone who came to take it could not finish it.
The elder brothers thought:
Is our younger brother Bhiká¹£u Phraá¹‡a able to make a living, or is he suffering from poverty?
They went together to see him, and saw that his younger brother's blessings and merits surpassed even the king's. They said to their younger brother:
You were previously poor, how did you suddenly become rich?
He replied:
I saw Gautama, gave him a bowl of food, and received such a reward.
When the four elder brothers heard this, they were overjoyed. They also said to their younger brother:
Now, make some joyful balls for us. The four of us will each hold one ball to offer to Gautama, wishing to be reborn in the heavens, not listening to his teachings, not using liberation.
Then they each carried joyful balls and went to where the Buddha was. The eldest brother took a ball and put it in the Buddha's bowl. The Buddha said:
All conditioned things are impermanent.
The second one also put a joyful ball in the Buddha's bowl, and the Buddha said this:
This is the Dharma of birth and cessation.
The third time, he put a ball of joy into the Buddha's bowl, and the Buddha said:
When birth and cessation cease.
The fourth time, he put a ball of joy into the Buddha's bowl, and the Buddha said:
Tranquil extinction is bliss.
He then returned home and went to a quiet place, and they asked each other:
What did you hear?
The eldest brother said:
I heard 'All conditioned things are impermanent.'
The next one heard 'the dharma of birth and cessation,' the next heard 'when birth and cessation cease,' and the fourth heard 'tranquil extinction is bliss.'
The four brothers each contemplated these verses, attained the stage of non-returner, and all came to the Buddha, seeking to go forth, and attained the path of arhatship.

The Causes and Conditions of MahÄprajÄpatÄ« Giving the Buddha a Gold-Embroidered Robe and a Pearl-Stringer (50) The Causes and Conditions of MahÄprajÄpatÄ« Giving the Buddha a Gold-Embroidered Robe and a Pearl-Stringer In the past, when the Buddha was in the world, MahÄprajÄpatÄ« made a gold-embroidered robe for the Buddha.
